thread.title: East meets west: Frank Brangwyn and Yoshijiro Urushibara's collaborations – in pictures
thread.title_full: East meets west: Frank Brangwyn and Yoshijiro Urushibara's collaborations – in pictures

author: Guardian Staff
title: East meets west: Frank Brangwyn and Yoshijiro Urushibara's collaborations – in pictures
text:
East meets west: Frank Brangwyn and Yoshijiro Urushibara's collaborations – in pictures East meets west: Frank Brangwyn and Yoshijiro Urushibara's collaborations – in pictures View more sharing options Share on Messenger Close 
Frank Brangwyn was an English former apprentice of William Morris, while Yoshijiro Urushibara was an expert Japanese woodblock artist. In the early part of the 20th century, they made prints together that blended their artistic styles and showed their shared adoration of nature Tuesday 14 February 2017 07.00 GMT Frank Brangwyn: The last of the HMS Britannia, c 1917 Frank Brangwyn (1867–1956), founder of the William Morris Gallery, was fascinated by Japanese art, and his collaborations with Yoshijiro Urushibara (1888–1953) took both artists to new heights Photograph: Frank Brangwyn/William Morris Gallery Frank Brangwyn: Portrait of Yamanaka, c 1931 Brangwyn was an apprentice to William Morris from 1882 to 1884, and, like Morris, took on many populist and accessible creative endeavours, painting murals, oils and watercolours; making prints and designing furniture, textiles, stained glass and ceramics Photograph: Frank Brangwyn/William Morris Gallery Frank Brangwyn: Swans, c 1921 His watercolours share Morris’s celebration of the beauty and nature Photograph: Frank Brangwyn/William Morris Gallery Yoshijiro Urushibara after Frank Brangwyn: Devil’s Bridge, St Gothard’s pass, c 1924 Urushibara, meanwhile, was born in Tokyo, but travelled to London in 1908, aged 19, for an exhibition of Japanese woodblock printing techniques. He was then hired by the British Museum to restore and reproduce prints in its collection Photograph: Yoshijiro Urushibara/William Morris Gallery Yoshijiro Urushibara: The Pines, c. 1928 His own work echoes the elegant beauty and slightly muted tones of Morris and Brangwyn, despite coming from a completely different tradition Photograph: Yoshijiro Urushibara/William Morris Gallery Yoshijiro Urushibara: Leaves from the Sketchbook of Frank Brangwyn, c 1940 The pair met and began collaborating, with Urushibara making woodblock prints from Brangwyn’s watercolours Photograph: Yoshijiro Urushibara/William Morris Gallery Yoshijiro Urushibara after Frank Brangwyn: Le Quai Vert, Bruges, c 1919 Their most ambitious and fully realised work was the Bruges series, with Brangwyn producing images of the Belgian city he grew up in and Urushibara translating them into prints Photograph: Yoshijiro Urushibara/William Morris Gallery Brangwyn’s design for the Sheer Pleasure gallery, c 1918–1920 Such was Brangwyn’s affinity with Japanese art that he designed a museum called Sheer Pleasure, to house western art in Tokyo – though the project was abandoned after its benefactor went bust Photograph: Frank Brangwyn/Courtesy of Liss Llewellyn Fine Art Yoshijiro Urushibara after Frank Brangwyn, detail from Leaves from the Sketchbook of Frank Brangwyn, 1940 Urushibara returned to Japan and exhibited in the US, while Brangwyn went on to complete murals for the Rockefeller Center, though he became a recluse after a major commission for the House of Lords was declined Photograph: William Morris Gallery/Yoshijiro Urushibara Topics
